newsitem.title: MEXICO: Mexico's PRI falls short of majority in lower house.
newsitem.headline: Mexico's PRI falls short of majority in lower house.

text.p: Mexico's long-ruling Institutional Revolutionary Party (PRI) has won 164 of the 300 directly elected seats in the lower house of Congress but has still fallen short of an outright majority, the final official count showed on Friday.

Under Mexico's complex electoral law the PRI needed at least 167 of the directly elected seats in the 500-seat chamber and 42.2 percent of the national vote to again clinch the absolute majority it has enjoyed for the past 68 years.

The result, still subject to appeal, gave the leftwing opposition Party of the Democratic Revolution (PRD) 70 deputies, followed closely by the conservative National Action Party (PAN) with 65. The PT workers party won one seat, the results from Mexico's Federal Electoral Institute said.
Another 200 seats have yet to be allocated under a system of proportional representation.
Sunday's watershed mid-term elections gave opposition parties unprecedented gains and ended the PRI's absolute hold on power.
The new multi-party chamber, which in the past has simply been a rubber stamp for legislation proposed by the president, will meet for the first time in September.
